About Me#Informatics student at Universitas Al Azhar Indonesia and an aspiring Cybersecurity Analyst with a keen interest in Defensive Security operations. My goal is to leverage an understanding of offensive tactics to build stronger, more resilient defenses against cyber threats. Committed to continuous learning in SOC environments, I am currently pursuing the Certified Defensive Security Analyst (CDSA) certification on Hack The Box.
LinkedInExperience#Universitas Al Azhar Indonesia, Jakarta [Apr 2025 - Aug 2025]
Laboratory Assistant for Programming Algorithms
Mentored a cohort of 40+ first-year students, providing guidance on core computer science concepts including Algorithm Complexity, Pseudocode design, and Python Data Structures. Facilitated practical sessions focused on searching techniques (Sequential, Binary), recursive functions, and sorting algorithms (Bubble, Insertion, Selection, Merge Sort). Conducted weekly code reviews and provided constructive feedback to enhance student code quality, readability, and algorithmic efficiency. Collaborated with the supervising lecturer to curate curriculum materials and ensured a conducive laboratory environment for daily operations. Leadership Activities#Informatics Student Association (HMIF), Universitas Al Azhar Indonesia [May 2024 - Mar 2025]
Secretary, Academic Department
Managed administrative and academic documentation to support departmental educational programs and internal operations. Conducted peer mentorship and tutoring sessions for Informatics students (Class of 2023), focusing on preparation for Midterm (UTS) and Final (UAS) examinations. Drafted and coordinated academic event proposals, ensuring alignment with departmental objectives and university regulations. Prepared and submitted University Allocation Fund (DAU) proposals, successfully securing funding for major academic initiatives. Compiled post-event accountability reports (LPJ) and financial documentation to ensure transparency and compliance. FORTEX 5.0 ‚Äì Informatics Exhibition 5.0 (National-Level Event) [Nov 2024 - Jan 2025]
Event Division Staff, HMIF Universitas Al Azhar Indonesia
Contributed to organizing FORTEX 5.0, HMIF‚Äôs largest annual program, featuring 2 offline talk shows on Data & AI and 2 national competitions (UI/UX Design & Data Science) attended by students across Indonesia. Designed the technical guidelines and competition mechanisms, creating detailed booklets and presentation decks to guide participants nationwide. Served as the Moderator for the UI/UX Design competition, effectively managing time constraints for 10-minute pitches and Q&A sessions between finalists and judges. Collaborated across departments to ensure seamless execution of both offline talkshows and online competition finals.

As an Informatics student, the curriculum covers a vast array of fields rather than specializing in one. My journey has been diverse‚ÄîI have built Mobile Apps, Web Apps, developed 3D Vector Graphics simulations, and even authored Statistical Research papers.
However, since discovering that Cybersecurity is my passion, I‚Äôve been eager to explore it further. Now, after 2 years in college, I finally have the chance to take a subject dedicated to security. This project serves as a showcase of that subject, moving beyond general programming into secure system architecture.
üéØ The Goal#In modern cloud storage, we often trade security for convenience. My goal was to build a “Secure Document Vault” backend that ensures:
Confidentiality: Files stored on the disk must be unreadable without the key. Integrity: The system must detect if a file has been tampered with. Performance: It must handle Batch Processing (uploading multiple files simultaneously) efficiently. The technical challenge was combining AES-256 (fast but hard to manage keys) with RSA-2048 (secure keys but slow for data) into a seamless Hybrid Model.
üõ†Ô∏è What Did I Do?#I engineered a REST API backend that acts as a secure vault. Instead of relying on a single encryption method, I built a layered security architecture.
The Tech Stack#Runtime: Node.js (v18) & Express.js Database: MongoDB (storing metadata like hash & wrapped keys) Cryptography: AES-256 (GCM & CBC modes), RSA-2048, SHA-256 Testing: Postman & Custom Scripting The Hybrid Mechanism#Here is how I solved the speed vs. security trade-off:
The file itself is encrypted using AES-256. This is incredibly fast. The ephemeral AES key (used only once) is then encrypted using the server’s RSA Public Key. I generated a SHA-256 hash of the original file to detect any tampering during storage. Why Hybrid? It allows us to process gigabytes of data with the speed of AES, while keeping the keys locked away with the mathematical rigor of RSA.üöÄ The Process#This wasn’t just about importing a crypto library; it was about architecture.
Phase 1: Designing the Architecture#I started by mapping out how data flows from the user to the disk. I decided on a Three-Tier Architecture to separate the client, the logic (Crypto Engine), and the storage layer.
Figure 1: Global System Architecture & Hybrid Encryption FlowPhase 2: The Batch Processing Challenge#Handling one file is easy. Handling 12 files at once in a single HTTP request is where it gets tricky. I used multipart/form-data to split the request body, allowing the system to process a mix of PDFs, images, and text files simultaneously.
Each file in the batch gets its own unique AES key and IV, ensuring that if one file is compromised, the others remain secure.
Phase 3: Benchmarking (The Fun Part)#I didn’t just assume it worked; I stress-tested it. I compared two AES modes: CBC (Cipher Block Chaining) vs. GCM (Galois/Counter Mode).
I ran tests with various datasets:
Small Batch: 3 mixed files. Medium Batch: 5 files (including dummy sensitive data). Large Batch: 12 files (stress test). Figure 2: Successful Batch Upload using Postmanüìä The Outcome#The results were surprisingly good. The system handled the “Large Batch” scenario (12 files) in just 100-148 ms.
Key Findings:#Encrypting the keys with RSA took only 1.56% of the total processing time (approx. 2ms). The fear that asymmetric encryption would slow down the system was debunked.
AES-CBC was slightly faster in raw encryption speed (83 MB/s). AES-GCM provided better security (Authenticated Encryption) and had 0 bytes of storage overhead. Metric AES-CBC AES-GCM Winner Speed 20 ms 24 ms CBC Overhead 16 bytes 0 bytes GCM Security Standard Authenticated GCM (Data derived from my benchmarks on 1.7MB files)
üí° Lessons Learned#Completing this project taught me that security is about architecture, not just algorithms.
Using standard, well-tested algorithms (AES/RSA) in a smart architecture is far better than trying to invent new ones. Implementing SHA-256 saved me from corrupted data multiple times during testing. It‚Äôs a simple check that adds massive reliability. Diving deep into Node.js streams and encryption modes allowed me to optimize the batch processing to be nearly instant. It was a steep learning curve, but seeing the “200 OK” green status on a batch encryption request was incredibly satisfying.
For a deep dive into the technical details, you can read my full report below:
Full Report (PDF)
summary: Exploring the balance between speed and security. A backend system that uses Hybrid Cryptography to handle secure batch document uploads without compromising performance.
title: Secure Document Vault: Hybrid Encryption
